Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: You notice a small, contained liquid spill in a walkway that needs to be O39eaned up immediately to prevent slips.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: An official explains that, because of a registration mismatch, the voter must complete a provisional ballot form before the station closes in ten minutes.
Story: I was hauling bricks across the site when I spotted a slick, oily puddle right in the middle of the walkway. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my head: “Keep it safe, keep it clean.” I knew if anyone slipped, it’d be on me. I grabbed a mop, but my phone buzzed—reminding me the polling station was closing soon. I rushed over, hands still gritty, and joined the line. When I finally reached the table, the official frowned at my ID. “There’s a mismatch. You’ll need to fill out a provisional ballot form, and we close in ten minutes.” She handed me a stack of paperwork. My mind raced. If I left now, the spill could cause an accident. But if I ran back to clean it, I’d lose my only chance to vote. I could feel the weight of both responsibilities pressing down, each demanding my attention, each unforgiving if I failed. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between duty to my coworkers’ safety and my right to have a say in the election.
